description: Vuurwapen Blog Bumpfire stocks are a relatively new phenomenon. Before that, it was just a "skill" people had developed by hooking a thumb in their belt and...something. I don't know.   Today, the NRA came out in support of regulations banning bumpfire stocks. I do not think this will be met with the unanimous support of NRA members - not because they love bumpfire, but because they don't want to cave on gun control. This approach has not been ineffective, but I suggest we try, just once, a slightly different course of action.  The SHARE act has reportedly been sidelined in the aftermath of the Las Vegas attack. It would, among other things, remove silencers from the NFA registry. Gun owners want it passed. Presumably, the NRA wants it passed. But instead of saying they'd support a bumpfire stock ban if the SHARE act was passed, they paid minor lip service to a national carry permit reciprocity deal at the end of their announcement - after everyone except me had stopped reading, I bet.   This should change. I'm willing to bet that unless you work for SlideFire Systems, you care less about the availability of bumpfire stocks than the cost and regulatory hassles associated with suppressors. Either way, I think the writing is on the wall for bumpfire stocks, and I think we should not let this opportunity pass us by.  I'd rather have useful cans than stupid pieces of plastic. I wish the NRA could say the same. Vuurwapen Blog Vuurwapen Blog
